text: Human T cell activation through the <extra_id_0> activation-inducer molecule <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> CD69 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhances the activity of transcription factor AP-1 .
The induction of the AP-1 transcription factor has been ascribed to the early events leading to T cell differentiation and activation .

We have studied the regulation of AP-1 activity in human peripheral blood T lymphocytes stimulated through the <extra_id_0> activation inducer molecule <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) / <extra_id_0> CD69 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation pathway .

Phorbol esters are required to induce <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> CD69 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cell-surface expression as well as for triggering the proliferation of T cells in conjunction with anti - <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb .

text: Mobility shift assays showed that addition of anti - <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb to PMA - treated T lymphocytes markedly enhanced the binding activity of AP-1 to its cognate sequence , the phorbol ester response element .

In contrast , anti - <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb did not induce any change in the binding activity of NF-kappa B , a transcription factor whose activity is also regulated by protein kinase C .

The increase in AP-1 - binding activity was accompanied by the marked stimulation of the transcription of <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but not that of <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Blockade of the DNA - binding complexes with an anti - <extra_id_0> Fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb demonstrated a direct participation of <extra_id_0> c-Fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the AP-1 complexes induced by anti - <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb .

text: Most of the AP-1 activity could be eliminated when the anti - <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb was added to the culture medium in the presence of cycloheximide , suggesting that de novo protein synthesis is crucial for the induction of AP-1 - binding activity .
These data provide the evidence that activation of human peripheral blood T cells through the <extra_id_0> AIM <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation pathway regulate the activity of AP-1 .
Therefore , this pathway appears as a crucial step in the initiation of early T cell activation events .
